We are so grateful for her long career of service to our nation. #JewishAmericanHeritageMonth

After 29 years of military service, SMSgt Berg still remains active today as an advocate for #womenvets issues and believes strongly in the power of outreach. Currently, she serves as Chair of the Jewish War Veterans‚Äô Women in the Military Committee.

She was also the first reserve 1st Sergeant to the mortuary at Dover, which the remains of soldiers of all branches are flown from overseas for burial ‚Äì an assignment of great responsibility that demands the greatest respect.
For the next 15 years of her career, she broke barriers as the first Non-Commissioned Officer in Charge (NCOIC) of Family Readiness for the Reserves at Dover Air Force Base.
The only woman in the post-basic training Jet Engine Mechanic Class, she went on to serve as mechanic on military aircrafts, including the large cargo C-5 and C-130, for 14 years.
After completing a Bachelors and Masters Degree in social work, Sheila Berg joined the Air Force Reserves seeking to serve our country. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E1YWUaxWYAAC4nW.jpg

Next in the #WomensVetsTaskForce series highlighting the achievements of groundbreaking Jewish American #womenvets, we recognize Senior Master Sergeant Sheila Berg, who was an Air Force mechanic while also maintaining her civilian career as a clinical social worker. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E1YWS03WEAAXOD7.jpg http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E1YWTdOX0AYMK-N.jpg

The mystery:

Why won‚Äôt @FarmBureau and @BeefUSA work with us on the text of this legislation for the benefit of their members?

Are you a member of one of these organizations? Please ask them why they don‚Äôt want to be part of this legislation to help small farmers.

The solution:

Our bipartisan, bicameral PRIME Act (which we are about to reintroduce) would allow small processors who comply with state regulations to sell within their states without being overly regulated by USDA.

The consequences:

Farmers are unable to get a fair price for their livestock, while the price of meat increases in grocery stores. Due to the centralized nature of the processing, shortages sometimes occur, and when outbreaks of food borne illness occur, it affects many states.

The problem:

Four corporations control 85% of meat processed in the United States. One of these companies is Chinese, one is Brazilian. Prices are going up in the supermarkets. The oligopoly is enabled by over-regulation of small American owned processors by the US government.
